skill.name: dast-ffuf
skill.description: Fast web fuzzer for DAST testing with directory enumeration, parameter fuzzing, and virtual host discovery. Written in Go for high-performance HTTP fuzzing with extensive filtering capabilities. Supports multiple fuzzing modes (clusterbomb, pitchfork, sniper) and recursive scanning. Use when: (1) Discovering hidden directories, files, and endpoints on web applications, (2) Fuzzing GET and POST parameters to identify injection vulnerabilities, (3) Enumerating virtual hosts and subdomains, (4) Testing authentication endpoints with credential fuzzing, (5) Finding backup files and sensitive data exposures, (6) Performing comprehensive web application reconnaissance.

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing no executable code. Provides guidance for using the legitimate open-source ffuf security tool. All files are template documentation with defensive security patterns. No network operations, file system access, or code execution paths present.

content.user_title: Discover hidden web resources with ffuf fuzzing
content.value_statement: Identify hidden directories, files, and parameters in web applications that could expose vulnerabilities. Use this skill to perform comprehensive reconnaissance during authorized security testing with the high-performance ffuf fuzzer.
actual_capabilities: Perform directory and file enumeration on web applications
Fuzz GET and POST parameters to discover hidden inputs
Test authentication endpoints with credential fuzzing
Find backup files and sensitive data exposures
Apply filters to reduce false positives in results
limitations: Only provides documentation and guidance, does not execute scans directly
Authorization and legal compliance user responsibility
Does not perform vulnerability exploitation or validation

prompt_templates.title: Basic directory scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Use ffuf to enumerate directories on https://target.example.com using a common wordlist. Show only 200 and 403 status codes.

prompt_templates.title: Parameter fuzzing
prompt_templates.prompt: Fuzz GET parameter names on https://api.target.com/endpoint to discover hidden parameters using ffuf with appropriate filtering.

prompt_templates.title: VHost discovery
prompt_templates.prompt: Discover virtual hosts on target.example.com using ffuf with Host header fuzzing. Filter by response size to identify valid vhosts.

prompt_templates.title: Auth testing
prompt_templates.prompt: Use ffuf in clusterbomb mode to test username and password combinations on https://target.com/login. Show matched responses only.

output_examples.input: Run ffuf directory enumeration on https://example.com with a common wordlist
output: Run deeper enumeration on discovered paths with file extensions (.bak, .sql, .zip)

best_practices: Obtain written authorization before testing any target system
Start with small wordlists and increase size gradually to avoid overwhelming targets
Use rate limiting (-p and -t flags) to respect target resources
anti_patterns: Using maximum concurrency without considering target capacity
Ignoring false positive filtering, causing noise in results

faq.question: What external tools does this skill require?
faq.answer: This skill requires ffuf (Fast Web Fuzzer) installed locally. Install via: go install github.com/ffuf/ffuf/v2@latest

faq.question: What wordlists should I use?
faq.answer: Common wordlists include SecLists Discovery directories and raft-small-files. Start small, then scale up based on results.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with CI/CD pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes, use the provided CI/CD template to run directory scans against staging environments. Export results in JSON format.

faq.question: Is credential fuzzing legal?
faq.answer: Only test systems you own or have explicit written authorization for. Testing third-party systems may violate computer fraud laws.

faq.question: How do I reduce false positives?
faq.answer: Use auto-calibration (-ac) or manual filtering by status code, response size, and word count to exclude baseline responses.

faq.question: How does this differ from other DAST tools?
faq.answer: ffuf is a focused fuzzer optimized for speed and flexibility. Use it for reconnaissance, then complement with ZAP or Burp for deeper analysis.
